footnotes.content: ἄ θροον, comp. Eus. Hist. Eccl. v. i. 29.
One ms. “not even distinguished by name had he not been of it. His,” &c.

[On the other hand, the facts that John’s father Zebedee had hired servants, that his mother Salome aided in the support of Jesus, that John was acquainted with the high-priest, and seems to have possessed a home in Jerusalem into which he took the mother of our Saviour after the crucifixion, prove that he was not the poorest among the fishermen, but in tolerably good circumstances. Comp. Mark ii. 20; Luke v. 10; viii. 3; Mark xvi. 1; John xviii. 15; xix. 27.—P.S.]
See above, p. 2 [4]. [From one ms. in the Bened. ed.—P.S.]
Empedocles said this. Vid. Diog. Laert. viii. 2. ῎ Ηδη γάρ ποτ̓ ἐγὼ γενόμην κοῦρός τε κόρη τε Θάμνος τ̓ οἵωνός τε καὶ ἐξ ἁλὸς ἔμπυρος ἰχθύς.
ἔ ρανον, a feast to which all the guests contributed.
i.e. Man is more tractable than brutes, the words of the Spirit more powerful than words of reason.
al. “one ever and through all time.”
τὰ ὄντα are opposed to τὰ γενόμενα in the Platonic philosophy. The reading here should be γενητῇ for γεννητῇ, as in the ms. Baroc. no. 210, in the Bodl. Library. Our Lord is γεννητὸς ἀγενητῶς.
οἰκονομία signifies all that Christ did and suffered on earth for the salvation of mankind. Vide Euseb. Hist. Ecc. i. 1, Not. 11, ed. Heinichen.
παρείληπται ἐπὶ τῆς οἰκονομίας, “adopted in reference to.”
i.e. gave up their salvation rather than offend others.
al. “but it may be seen from this.”
τὸ αὐτὸ δὴ τοῦτο ἔστιν οὕτως ὡς ἐκείνῃ οὐσίᾳ πρέπον ἦν.
i.e. the things of the invisible world, opposed to ὁ ρατὰ.
i.e. applied alike to the different Persons in the Holy Trinity.
Isa. xi. 10 , as quoted Rom. xv. 12; Rev. xxii. 16.
ἀ παραλλαξία vid. supra, Hom. iii. 4 ad fin.
[καὶ πρὸς αὐτὸν], perhaps “and with reference to him (the Baptist), Sav. al. καὶ πρὸς σέ.
αὐτοῦ ἣν μαρτυρεῖ περὶ ἐμοῦ G. T.

Paul of Samosata, Bishop of Antioch, denied the Personality of our Lord before His Birth of the Virgin Mary. His opinions were condemned, and himself deposed, at the second Council of Antioch, A.D. 270.
Zenobia, Queen of Palmyra, who supported Paul against the Catholics after his deposition.
οἰκονομήσοντα, lit. “would dispense as He did dispense.”
al. “for they had both heard His voice, and seen Him, but not in the flesh.”

i.e. that the power which maintains the universe is a power opposed to the True God. The Gnostics accounted for the existence of evil, by supposing an evil Principle, to which they attributed the creation and support of the material world. The opinions here spoken of were maintained by Basilides, Valentinus, Marcion, Manes, and other supporters of that heresy.
θολοῖ from θολὸς, “the ink of the cuttle fish.”
γνησίως, perhaps “as befits a rightful heir.”
Or “with much openness,” i.e. before angels and men.
al. “he does all things that he may empty.”
ὑ ποσκελίσαι (a gymnastic term like the preceding).
δεσποτείας, i.e. “the law of master and slave.”
al. “For, when the former way is disregarded, the introduction of the second is necessary.” Ben.
στηλιτεύεσθαι. lit. “set on a pillar.” al. στίζεσθαι, “be branded.”
παρουσία, commonly so used in N.T.
al. “there is reason to wonder that.”
παροινήθεντος, “insulted by men heated with wine.”
al. “sets them in brief before us in these words.”
al. “let him mark what is clear, &c.”
i.e. having come to the assembly.
μετέπεσεν, “fall from what It was into.”

The Docetæ, who maintained that our Lord appeared only to act and suffer in the Flesh, and that His Body was a phantom. Perhaps they are the heretics specially alluded to by St. John, 1 Ep. iv. 2, and 2 Ep. 7.
al. “that it was not otherwise than by.”
Morel. “make the intolerable (brightness) of his countenance bearable to them.”
Morel. “and heavenly multitudes appearing on earth of Angels ministering.”
There are places where he allows that the prayers of others may avail a man in the Judgment, when they are the consequence of his good deeds. See on Statues, Hom. ii. § 17.
al. “this may be learnt from Ezekiel.”

No such passage is extant in Josephus. Probably the place alluded to is Antiq. b. xviii. c. 5, § 2, where the destruction of the troops of Herod the tetrarch by Aretas is attributed to the death of John the Baptist.
Ben. “the war through which the city of the Jews, which was once the mother city, is no city.”
Morel. καὶ πάντα τὰ αὐτοῦ ὄντως ἀνεζήτη, ὡς καὶ περὶ τῆς ἀώρου ἡλικίας τῆς σφαττομένης.
Morel. inserts “hence, away with the thought.”
Morel. “as obeying it in all things: but they who yet moved below, needed also many other (things), because of their groveling on the ground, and being wrapt.”
Morel. and ms. Savile reads προστιθέασι τῇ πτήσει πάλιν καὶ … πλείονα συνάπτουσιν.
Some mss. add, “but being able to possess the souls of the many with much fearlessness.”
ἔ λεον. St. Chrysostom plays on the word, which was pronounced nearly as ἔ λαιον, “oil.” Thus on 2 Tim. ii. 25, Hom. vi.
τὰ δευτερεῖα προσενεγκών. St. Chrysostom implies, that the offering of Cain was not of his best.
Morel. “sit down in the heavenly bride-chamber.”
in Orig. “the house of Israel and Judah.”
ἀ ναστοιχειωθέντες, made up of fresh elements.
So Morel. Ben. and ms. in Bodleian. Savile reads οὐ πολλὴν.

Morel. and ms. in Bodleian read the passage thus: “are holy, but the (Holiness) of God is greater than their holiness, and surpassing, as in comparison with us, so also with the powers which are above us.”
Morel. and ms. in Bodleian, read, “and the adoption through the Spirit, given to us.”
al. “having from a few learned the whole.”
εἰς σύνεσιν מַשְׂכִּיל Maschil, σύνεσις, intellectus, et ut Hieron. reddit, eruditio, aliqui, erudiens, vel intellectum præstans. Lorin. in tit. Ps. 31 (32).
Some mss. read “silver, and search for it as treasure; He would not have said Search, &c.”
al. therefore saith (Paul), “Who was manifested in the flesh,” for the manifestation, &c.
lit. “He Who Is.” Another reading of the passage is, “if he were asked…and should answer, he is bidden to say that, &c.”
μεγάλης βουλῆς ἄγγελος. The LXX. version of the titles of Christ, Isa. ix. 6.
al. “let us then so care for our neighbors, as not neglecting each his own flesh.”

Morel, “in like manner one may see in Luke, (iii. 16 ,) John saying to those who reasoned concerning him whether he was the Christ, that “One mightier than I cometh,” and by his answer again removing such a suspicion.”
Morel. and ms. in Bodl. “seest thou how, disguising what they had, they add.”
Morel. and ms. in Bodl. “they attempt to involve him in an accusation, compelling him.”
τὴν δόξαν τοῦ πέμψαντος αὐτὸν, G. T.
Morel. and ms. in Bodl. “for thus Paul speaks of the saints concerning whom he writes, ‘of whom,’ etc.”
Morel. and ms. in Bodl. “boldly speaking out, (ἀ παυθαδιαζομένους,) say that, &c.”
Ecclus. x. 12 , LXX. ἀ νθρώπου ἀφισταμένου ἀπὸ τοῦ K. Eng. ver. “when one departeth.”
al. “how then doth he this? adding and saying.”
Morel and ms. in Bodleian, “much more would the disciples have been thus affected, and when they had come would have been subdued by His words.”
Morel. reads: καὶ ὑποψίας ἦν μετὰ τὸ κήρυγμα λοιπόν.
Morel. and ms. in Bodl. “this also may be seen with Paul.”
i.e. with the foxes and birds.
Morel. and ms. in Bodl. “and David also glances at this, saying.”
Ben. Morel. and ms. in Bodl. read the passage thus: “For this cause also marriage is arranged, in order that what is wanting,” &c.
καθάπερ οὖν καὶ θνητὴν γενομένην. Ben. and ms. in Bodl. read, ὡ ς αὔτην ἔχειν και θ. γ.
Morel. and ms. in Bodl. “conversed with them, when they straightway followed and abode with Him.”
Ben. Morel. and ms. in Bodl. “he showed hence, for he both establishes the wisdom,” &c.
i.e. those mentioned above, v. 40 , who were present when St. John Baptist gave his testimony, one of whom was Andrew.
al. “And I say unto thee, ‘Thou art Simon, thou shalt be called Cephas, which is by interpretation a stone.’”

ὅ περ δήπου καὶ ̔Ηλίας πεποίηκε, and there are no various readings. Savile has in the margin ὅ περ οὖν καὶ ̔Ηλία. We may venture to read “ἡ Λεία,” as he praises her for this, Hom. lvi. on Genesis. “Observe how she gave names to those she bore, not lightly nor at random.”
παντὶ τῷ μεριμνῶντι ἔνεστί περισσόν. In the next sentence Morel. Ben. and most mss. read ὅ θεν καὶ ἔπεισί μοι. Savile ὅ θ. οὐδὲ ἔπ. μ. which seems the better reading.
ὡ ς ἄνθρωπον ἐξήταζεν. So Morel. and mss. in Bodleian. Savile and the Bened. read ὡ ς ἄνθρωπος, “he enquired as a man.”
One ms. reads, οὐ γὰρ εἴπεν, ἄνωθέν σε οἶδα, καὶ τὸν τρόπον, καὶ τὴν ἐπ.
ἵ να μάθῃ. Savile conjectures ἵ να μάθῃς, but without authority.
Ben. Conj. καλοῦντι for καλῶν τις. “But if he mind not when he calls.”
Morel. and ms. in Bodleian read the passage thus: πολλοὶ τῶν ἀναγινωσκόντων τὸ ῥητὸν τοῦτο διαποροῦντες φάσι· τί δήποτε Πέτρος κ.τ.λ.
Matt. xiii. 24, 25 , slightly varying from G. T.

τὸ πᾶν, i.e. the fabric of the human body.

Morel. and ms. in Bodl. “but if it is impossible to reply to these questions, how shall it not be more impossible to speak concerning the unseen and far higher Generation? or rather, how is it not superfluous to demand reasons,” &c.
[as it is allowed me from above] Morel.

Morel. “having been immersed below, is hidden wholly once for all.” [The whole passage is important for the patristic view of the mode of baptism.—P.S.]
lit “of bloods,” as in c. i. 13.

So Savile and mss. Morel.’s reading has the same sense, but is less clear and concise.
ὃ ἑώρ καὶ ἤκ τοῦτο μ. G. T.

al. being asked for water by Christ; for, “Give Me to drink,” the Evangelist tells us, was what Christ said to her. What then saith she? “How is it,” &c.
c. vii. 49. al. “is not this people,” &c.

al. “the actions,” i.e. of the Gospel.
Morel. “beholding the devil shamed by means of the Divine oracles, and greatly striving.” Below Morel. reads, “run to such a sight.”

σκάμματα, διαύλους, λαβὰς, terms of the wrestling school. σκάμμα, the place dug out for the exercise, hence the exercise itself. δίαυλος, the double course. λαβὴ, the gripe of the wrestler. Thus of Job, on Stat. Hom. i. 16; of the Three Children, ib. Hom. iv. 8, &c.
This clause is not found in Ben.
The passage is read differently in the ms. in Bodl. “not willing them to continue in those ancient (practices).”
ms. in Bodl. “this is to worship in truth.”
ms. in Bodl. “the law of Moses.”
ms. in Bodleian, “for, saith the Evangelist, Peter looks on the disciple.”
i.e. St. Peter loved his Lord, and therefore we infer that he was loved of Him; of St. John Scripture speaks expressly, as being “the Disciple whom Jesus loved.”
ὃ ς οὐ λαμβάνει κ.τ.λ. G. T.
ἠ ρώτων. E.V. prayed: Ben and ms. in Bodl. ἠ ρώτων ἐνταῦθα παρεκαλοῦν ἐστὶ, τῇ ἐγχωρίῳ αὐτῶν φωνῇ
i.e. given by means of things which are objects of experience. ὑ πογραφὴ πείρας, al. πείρα

There is no authority for a different reading, but it seems to be rightly conjectured by Savile and Ben. that the names “Daniel” and “David” should be transposed. The proverb is that used by David, 1 Sam. xxiv. 13 , and the other passage alluded to may be Dan. xii. 10 , “the wicked shall do wickedly.” ms. in Bodl. reads, ἀ νομία ἐκ βαβυλῶνος for ἐ ξ ἀνόμων πλημμελεία
ms. in Bodl. “as soon as they heard the woman they believed, for they,” &c.

Εἰς πῦρ ξαίνοντι. Plat. Legg. vi. p. 750. “And like,” &c. is not in the text of Savile.
i.e. of Redemption. πᾶσαν τὴν πραγματείαν συνεστήσατο
ms. in Bodl. reads, “and why say I of a lost world? of a world which was in evils great exceedingly.”
ms. in Bodl. “and this is, that ‘ a prophet hath no honor in his own country. ’”
ms. in Bodl. reads, “and why, saith some one, went He again to Cana?”
Mark ix. 24 [not found in St. Luke].

Morel. “and regarded only what was taking place concerning his son.”
ms. in Bodl. reads, “He said this as (He said) to the disciples, ‘ Believe, ’” &c.

προβατικὴ κολυμβήθρα [ἐ πὶ τῇ π. G. T.].
al. “harm the faith of the hearers.”

i.e. the manifest hopelessness of his being able to go down first into the pool.
Morel and ms. in Bodl. “but hear also the explanation, for this we will now say for love of you. What then,” &c.

Morel. and ms. in Bodl. read, “for having heard that with authority, and as one commanding, He said to him, ‘ Arise, ’” &c.
Morel and ms. “who had commanded, ‘ Arise, ’” &c.

Morel and ms. “accusing, as the Evangelist shows by what follows, saying, ‘ And on the same day was the Sabbath. The Jews therefore said unto him that was cured, It is the Sabbath day, it is not lawful, ’” &c.
ἐ ξέκλινεν ἐξένευσεν, G. T. and Mor.

Ben. and ms. in Bodl. read the passage thus: “For the chastisement was of itself sufficient…but when not being sobered by the application of punishment, he again dares the same things, such an one will reasonably suffer some penalty, calling this as he does upon his own self.”
ἐ φόδιον γίγνεται. So Euseb. H. E. viii. 10, ἐ φ. τῆς εἰς τὴν ζωὴν εἰσόδου
ἀ προσώπως, i.e. not referring to Himself.
Jericho was taken on the seventh day by command of God. Josh. vi. 4, 15
lit. “weldeth.” συγκροτεῖ. Sav. conjectures συγκρατεῖ, but the word is not uncommon for holding together a system.

τῆς αὐτῆς γνώμης ἀπόφασίς, i.e. in saying that He was making Himself “equal to the Father,” the Evangelist asserts a truth which had before been signified by His breaking the Sabbath, and saying that God was His Father.
Morel. and ms. in Bodl., “that the ‘ likewise ’ (τὸ ὁμοίως) may remain.”
i.e. as well as of earthly things.
al. “since men being benefited are not so sensible of it, He saith ‘ hath given all judgment to ’ Him, in order that,” &c.
al. “to punish and honor all whomsoever He will.”
al. “all things which belong to the Father, belong also to the Son.”
For from their extreme senselessness He was counted among them an enemy of God. Morel.
al. “not that He might by this show any lessening,” &c.
κιρνᾶ, generally of mixing wine with water.
Morel. reads: “for this reason He doth not decline to use a more earthly expression, declaring,” &c.
Morel. reads: “He spake those great things in words, afterwards He desireth to prove them by works also.”
τὸ ἀπαράλλακτον καὶ ἑνὶ μόνῳ τὴν διαφορὰν ἐμφαῖνον
So Morel. and ms. in Bodl. Savile reads, “having shown that they,” &c.
According to Savile’s conjectural reading, παρὰ τὸ τοῦ Π. in place of παρὰ τοῦ Π. for which there is also ms. authority.
Savile reads, “and to the Jews, How say ye,” &c.
al. “let us see then with what intent these words were said.”
Morel. reads, “a ll but conclusively refuting them by what He saith.”
This passage is read variously in Ben. and ms. but without any variety of meaning.

al. “and promised all those things so as to draw them to Himself.”
or, “to take on them such hostility as they would have incurred by following Him.”

al. “to enquire even if He held His peace.”
εἰς τὰ μέρη, not in G. T.
al. “this kind of following belongs not to a settled mind.”
Not exactly quoted from 1 Cor. xiv. 22 , where the words relate the gift of tongues.

Ps. vii. 9 , or St. Paul, Rom. viii. 27
i.e. the Equality of The Son with The Father.
al. “for I think that the miracles of the Prophets had entered his mind.”
[of that which is set on.] Morel. and Ben.
In Ben. the reading is: “for when the loaves had not yet appeared, He doth the miracle.” This looks like the gloss of a transcriber, surprised at the suspension of the sense.

These words, which are not found in G. T., are quoted in place of v. 10. 11. “And Jesus said, Make the men sit down. Now there was much grass in the place. So the men sat down, in number about five thousand. And Jesus took the loaves; and when He had given thanks, He distributed to the disciples, and the disciples to them that were set down; and likewise of the fishes as much as they would.”
“When they were filled, He said.” N.T.
“That nothing be lost. Therefore they gathered them together, and filled twelve baskets with the fragments of the five barley loaves, which remained over and above unto them that had eaten.” N.T.
i.e. the Gnostics, see note, p. 30.
In place of ver. 14. “Then those men, when they had seen the miracle that Jesus did, said, This is of a truth that Prophet which should come into the world.”
al. “wherefore elsewhere they said, Is this,” &c.
Ben. “they having been left behind by their Master, when,” &c.
Ben. “not to go to seek Him.”
al. “is shown (or It shows by the Evangelist, saying,” &c.).
“at the land whither they went,” N.T.
al. “so that the beholders might both marvel, and not count them very strange.”
i.e. that it was really Christ.

N.T. ver. 22–24. “The day following, when the people which stood on the other side of the sea saw that there was none other boat there save that one whereinto His disciples were entered and that Jesus went not with His disciples into the boat, but that His disciples were gone away alone; (howbeit there came other little boats from Tiberias nigh unto the place where they did eat bread, after that the Lord had given thanks;) when the people therefore saw that Jesus was not there, neither His disciples, they also took shipping, and came to Capernaum seeking for Jesus.” The readings here vary, without variety of meaning.
ἐ πιουσίον, i.e. εἰς τὴν ἐπίουσαν ἡμ
al. “no pains, but rather neither to have nor to desire them.”
Ben. omits “but by plundering, and taking more than their due.”
al. For He all but saith this in what He directeth against them: “It was not,” &c.
al. “are called by God a way, for there is one broad, and one strait and narrow ; but things to come,” &c.
al. “that we may also be able to attain them.”
al. “and ye receive not our witness,” as in N.T.
S. C. here instead of τί θέλω ; reads τί ἤθελον ἰδεῖν

In place of the passage which follows, Savile notices in the margin another reading: “Besides at a later time He said, (Luke xiii. 34 ,) ‘ How often would I have gathered thy children together, and ye would not! ’ what is it then that He saith? Nothing else but,” &c.

Sabellius was a bishop in Upper Egypt in the third century. The heresy which bears his name denies the Personality of the Son and the Holy Spirit, and holds that they are manifestations or characters of the Godhead.

Ver. 19, 20. “And Pilate wrote a title, and put it on the Cross, and the writing was, Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews. This title then read many of the Jews, for the place where Jesus was crucified was nigh to the city, and it was written in Hebrew, and Greek, and Latin.”
Ver. 21, 22. “Then said the chief priests of the Jews to Pilate, Write not, The King of the Jews, but that he said, I am King of the Jews. Pilate answered, What I have written, I have written.” N.T.

Ver. 23, 24. “Then the soldiers, when they had crucified Jesus, took His garments, and made four parts, to every soldier a part; and also His coat; now the coat was without seam, woven from the top throughout. They said therefore among themselves, Let us not rend it, but cast lots for it, whose it shall be, that the Scripture might be fulfilled which saith, They parted My raiment among them, and for My vesture they did cast lots.” N.T.

Ver. 25–27. “Now there stood by the Cross of Jesus His mother, and His mother’s sister, Mary the wife of Cleophas, and Mary Magdalene. When Jesus therefore saw His mother, and the disciple standing by whom He loved, He saith unto His mother, Woman, behold thy son. Then saith He to the disciple, Behold thy mother. And from that hour that disciple took her to his own home.”

Ver. 38–40. “And after this Joseph of Arimathæa, being a disciple of Jesus, but secretly for fear of the Jews, besought Pilate that he might take away the body of Jesus; and Pilate gave him leave. He came therefore, and took the body of Jesus. And there came also Nicodemus, which at the first came to Jesus by night, and brought a mixture of myrrh and aloes, about an hundred pound weight. Then took they the body of Jesus, and wound it in the linen clothes with the spices, as the manner of the Jews is to bury.”

συναλιζόμενος αὐτοῖς ἦν. The words are rendered as above in the margin of the Auth. Version, and St. Chrys. seems to have so understood them. The Vulgate has, “convescens ” The literal sense is either “eating salt with them,” or, as in the text of Auth. Version, “ being assembled with.”
